Participants.evidence: conducted in a tertiary medical center in East Asia, evaluated excisional hemorrhoidectomies

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to investigate whether the combination of general anesthesia plus local infiltration (GAL) is associated with lower complications and reduced pain compared to spinal anesthesia (SA)

Method_Outcome.evidence: Data on the six most common complications-pain, constipation, acute urine retention (AUR), bleeding, nausea, and headache-were extracted from medical records

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 550 hemorrhoidectomies were included: 220 in the GAL group and 330 in the SA group

Result_Outcome.evidence: The AUR rate was significantly lower in the GAL group compared to the SA group (15.5% vs. 32.1%, P < 0.001)

Harms.evidence: Overall, the GAL group exhibited a lower rate of adverse effects (56.9% vs. 67.4%, P = 0.023)
